utterances: I'm sorry, I can't disclose that because I've seen many of them, but many important people, many key figures on both sides of the - in the House and in the Senate.
Your mission here has been to persuade the minds of others.
I'm curious whether or not - in any of the conversations you've had here, have they changed your outlook on the situation in Iraq?
They have.
They certainly have.
And I've been very interactive with them.
And we in Iraq did not see very clearly the seriousness of this debate and the consequences of what might happen if they decide to a precipitous withdrawal or even putting a timeline for withdrawal.

That's why while we have changed - I have changed my position and I understood - I understand their position very, very well, I'm going to take it back to my prime minister and to my government, and we're going to seriously consider what is going on in Washington.
And we will determine - we've already decided and we're very determined to move ahead on political progress and make a political progress in the next few months.
Mowaffak al Rubaie is Iraq's national security adviser.
He joined us from Washington, D.C.
Thank you so much, sir.
Thank you, Alex.
Thank you very much indeed for having me.

A federal judge in this city did not give her final, final ruling yesterday in the case of President Trump's lawyer, but she says she has confidence in federal prosecutors, and she has not yet appointed an outside official to review documents seized from Michael Cohen.
NPR's Miles Parks was in the courtroom for hours yesterday as this case was argued.
He's here in our New York bureau.
Hey there, Miles.
Hi, Steve.
So would you just walk us through this?
What exactly is it that Michael Cohen wants done with the documents that were seized by the FBI the other day?
So basically it's all about attorney-client privilege.

Both sides are arguing that they should get the first crack at deciding of everything that was seized on last Monday - who should basically get the first crack of deciding what's protected under attorney-client privilege rules.

We should note that attorney-client privilege rules, they don't cover all communications between an attorney and the person they represent - only situations where the attorney is actually providing legal advice and situations where an attorney is actually not breaking the law in providing that legal advice by committing fraud or another crime.
OK.
Let's remember, federal prosecutors say they already did something to protect any privileged communications because these documents go to this separate team, right?
But Michael Cohen wanted something else and, in fact, lawyers for President Trump wanted something else.
Right.
They basically argue that they're in a unique position - also most incentivized - to basically make - get this privileged situation right.
They don't want the government to have a hand in deciding what's protected by their attorney-client privilege and what's not.
Meaning that Cohen was saying, well, let me decide whether...
Yeah, he was basically arguing - which the judge seemed to basically throw out.
That doesn't seem like a realistic possibility at this point.

Cohen's team did say, however, that if they weren't going to be able to - if it wasn't going to be them and it wasn't going to be Donald Trump's lawyers who get the first crack at this, they want an outside investigator, an outside attorney, something called the special master, to be brought in as a third party to look over this privilege question and decide.
What did the judge, Kimba Wood, eventually say?

She basically said she didn't have a decision yet, but she was torn between the protocols that are in place in the Justice Department, which is bring in this - what's called a filter team, which is an outside team - right?
- brought in to look at these documents or bring in a special master, this third party.
She still wants to get a better understanding of the scope of what was taken in the raid before she makes her decision.
OK.
So talk me through something else, Miles Parks.
Michael Cohen is asked, who are your other clients?
There's a client whose name we don't know.
Will you please name that client?
And he says Sean Hannity of Fox News.
You're in the courtroom.
And it was honestly one of the most extraordinary moments.
Yesterday in general was one of the most extraordinary moments of anything I've ever covered.
The air absolutely left the courtroom.
There were some giggles and then huge gasps and then, like, seven or eight journalists just ran out, presumably to go tweet or something like that.
Or something, yeah.
That was - that's reminding me of a scene in the movie ""Airplane!"" where all the reporters run into phone booths and knock over the phone booths because they're running so fast.
Yeah, exactly.
I mean, there was audible shock.
OK.
So just so we're clear, Hannity is involved how?
In what way is he a client of Michael Cohen?
(As Coraline Jones) You're not my mother.
My mother doesn't have buttons.

Track number 10 is ""Cowboy Sweetheart,"" and to this day, I can still remember me up in my room for a good five, six hours just, you know, repeating the song, repeating the song because the yodeling part was so cool - so cool.
And I just, I remember thinking I have to know how to do that.
I have to.
Barnell says her voice teacher has banned yodeling while she studies more classical repertoire.
But she says some days, she feels like chucking Scarlatti and haunting down a yodeling job at Disney World.
For NPR News, I'm Charlotte Albright in Portland, Maine.
(Soundbite of song, ""Wind It Up"")
(As Maria Von Trapp) (Singing) High on the hill was a lonely goatherd.
(Soundbite of yodeling)
We're playing this just in case you thought yodeling is a public radio sort of thing.
It's actually much cooler than we are.
It has made it the dance clubs, thanks to Gwen Stefani and a hip-hop beat.
The song ""Wind It Up"" is a song that uses ""The Lonely Goatherd"" from ""The Sound of Music."" And it reached number six on Billboard's Hot 100 chart in December.
(Soundbite of song, ""Wind it Up"")
(Singing) They can't touch, but the girls want to know why the boys like us so much.
They like the way we dance.
They like the way we work.
They like that way that lamb is going across my shirt.
They like the way my pants, it compliments my shape.
They like the way we act every time we dance.
Every time the basic thing, realize he calls your name.
This is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Debbie Elliott.
We certainly stirred up a hornet's nest, or rather a hen's nest, last weekend with our interview about white eggs and brown eggs.

It seemed uncontroversial at the time when Marie Simmons, the author of a cookbook called The Good Egg, told me that white-feathered chickens lay white eggs and brown-feathered chickens lay brown eggs.
Well, the mail came pouring in, to us and to the NPR blog Mixed Signals.
Most comments were from outraged poultry enthusiasts of one feather or another who swear that feather color is not the determining factor.

Your egg expert clearly knows next to nothing about chickens, wrote listener Evelyn Knight(ph), and from Tom Fiarello(ph), I really expect better from NPR, especially ATC, to which I've listened for 35 years.
Then there was seven-year-old Noah(ph) from Wetumpka, Alabama, who has four chickens and wrote, That is so not true.
Well, with so many feathers ruffled, we decided to launch a full-scale journalistic investigation.
The answer is a little complicated.
We've done our best to unscramble it for you.
The most reliable way to predict whether a chicken will lay a brown egg or a white egg is to look at its earlobes.
Yes, chickens have earlobes.
Chickens with white earlobes lay white eggs.
Those with red earlobes lay brown eggs.

But in defense of our guest, cookbook author Marie Simmons, let us state clearly that there is a close correlation between earlobe color and feather color, especially in commercial chickens, and Marie Simmons did get her information from the very reputable American Egg Board.
You know, the people who came up with the incredible edible egg?
One of the people we called to crack this case was Dr. Hillary Thesmar of the Egg Nutrition Center.
She pointed out that most lay people don't actually believe chickens have earlobes, so it's just easier to talk feathers.
But rules, like eggs, were made to be broken, so there are some brown-feathered chickens that have white earlobes and lay white eggs, and vice versa.
We also called Richard Gast, a microbiologist for the U.S.
Department of Agriculture's Egg Safety and Quality Research Unit.
He fessed up.
He'd never really given chicken earlobe color a moment's thought, but he generously tried to redirect our energies.
He said the main reason the white-shelled eggs are more popular in the U.S.
is that the chickens who lay them are smaller, eat less feed, and are therefore more cost efficient as egg producers.
There it is in an eggshell.
Now, if only we could answer which came first.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
The Agriculture Department has exhumed the body of an Alabama cow that was identified this week as the third U.S.
case of mad cow disease.
They're also working to trace the herd mates and offspring of that cow.
The task is made more difficult by the fact that, unlike Canada, Europe and Japan, the U.S.
still does not have a national tracking system for livestock.
And as NPR's Greg Allen reports, ranchers aren't sure they want to help the government keep track of their cattle through a national database.

The Agriculture Department announced Monday that a downer cow, that is, a cow that could no longer walk, had been euthanized and tested positive for mad cow disease, but aside from that, Jean Halloran of Consumers Union says it's surprising how little is known about this animal.
We know it's a cow, but we really know very little about where it's lived or what it's eaten along the way.
That's important because mad cow disease is spread through contaminated feed, feed that contains ground-up parts of other cows that had the disease.
That practice was banned nine years ago.

The USDA says the Alabama cow appears to have been at least ten years old, at least that's the judgment of the vet who euthanized the cow and who based his estimate upon examination of the animal's teeth, but as Halloran says, the animal's exact age and questions about how and where it may have contracted mad cow disease remain a mystery because, in this country, there's no system to identify and track livestock.

In other countries, they'll put a little computer chip on the cow or give it something like a bar code, and you track the animal from the day it's born to the supermarket, and you know exactly where it's been and who's owned it and what it's eaten.
For years, industry and government officials have discussed plans for a national animal identification system, and those talks got more serious after the first U.S.
case of mad cow disease was discovered in 2003.
But despite that, adoption of any national system still appears to be years away, and few cattle producers seem to want to speed up the process.
(Soundbite of cows mooing)
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's very unclear at this point exactly how he's involved with Michael Cohen.
This was not addressed at the hearing.
But Hannity says he has never paid a legal fee to Michael Cohen.
We're still kind of waiting for more details.
